headline: The Hip-Hop Artists Who Use Words To Change The World
short descr: These 43 people from around the world use music to advocate for peace and human rights.
image_caption(s): Emmanuel Jal, pictured performing live in London, was born in South Sudan. He uses his music to transform pain from the past into positivity for the future. Throughout his career, he's launched several projects, such as "We Want Peace" together with D.M.C., Alicia Keys and others. Being a former child soldier, he says music became his painkiller and he wants to share his experiences in order to inspire people to live in peace.

headline: The Hip-Hop Artists Who Use Words To Change The World
short descr: These 43 people from around the world use music to advocate for peace and human rights.
image_caption(s): Fatou Diatta is also known as Sister Fa. She is constantly fighting for human rights and against, in particular, female genital cutting. She travels in Senegal and parts of Western Africa to stop the traditional practice and to inform young people that they have a choice and a right to avoid this harm. She gives workshops and concerts in secluded areas.

headline: The Hip-Hop Artists Who Use Words To Change The World
short descr: These 43 people from around the world use music to advocate for peace and human rights.
image_caption(s): Deeb is an Egyptian rap artist who performed in Tahrir Square in Cairo during the Egyptian Revolution. He is popular for his comprehensible way of addressing political, social and cultural issues.

headline: Who Is Finished Paying Their 2017 Social Security Taxes? Probably Not You.
authors: Teresa Ghilarducci, ContributorEconomics professor, The New School for Social Research
short descr: Extreme earnings inequality explains the Social Security shortfall because Social Security taxes are only collected on incomes below an earnings cap. In 2016, the cap was $118,500 (which is indexed to average wage growth, not the wage growth at the top).
